channel.title: Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) Pollution
channel.description: Updated Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) Pollution content from the US Environmental Protection Agency

item.title: SO2 Data Requirements Rule State Pathway Notifications
item.description:
Related Information

  • SO2 Data Requirements Rule
  • SO2 Data Requirements Rule Source List
  • SO2 Data Requirements Rule State Pathway Notifications

Under the SO2 Data Requirements Rule (DRR), air agencies were required, by July 1, 2016, to notify EPA of their selected approach for characterizing air quality around each SO2 source that is subject to 40 CFR 51.1203. The DRR provided state air agencies with the following four options for meeting the DRR pathway requirement:

  1. Air quality modeling.
  2. Air quality monitoring.
  3. Adopt federally enforceable emission limits for a source to reduce emissions below 2,000 tpy, unless further air quality characterization is required in the judgment of the air agency or EPA.
  4. Submit documentation that a source has permanently shut down by January 13, 2017.

SO2 Data Requirements Rule State Pathway Notifications (July 1st):

In some cases, in addition to the pathway notifications, the files below include modeling protocols, monitoring plans and/or other information.

For questions concerning a state’s complete submittal, please contact the regional office associated with the affected state. 

  • DRR State Notification Pathway (PDF)(9 pp, 362 K, Sep 19, 2016)

item.title: Fact Sheets and Additional Information Regarding the 2012 Decision to Retain the Secondary NAAQS for Nitrogen Dioxide and Sulfur Dioxide
item.description:
On April 3, 2012, EPA decided to retain the current secondary national ambient air quality standard (NAAQS) for nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and sulfur dioxide (SO2).

This page contains a fact sheet and a presentation describing that action.

For more information, visit the 2012 NO2 and SO2 NAAQS page.

  • Fact Sheet: Final Revisions to the Secondary National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) for Oxides of Nitrogen and Sulfur (PDF)(4 pp, 82 K, March 20, 2012)
    This fact sheet provides an overview of the secondary NAAQS for oxides of nitrogen and sulfur.
  • July 2011 Proposed Revisions to the Secondary National Ambient Air Quality Standards for Oxides of Nitrogen and Oxides of Sulfur: Overview (PDF)(14 pp, 461 K, July 12, 2011)
    This presentation provides an overview of the Secondary NAAQS for oxides of nitrogen and sulfur.
item.dc:creator: rcopland

item.title: Table of Historical Sulfur Dioxide National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS)
item.description:
History of the National Ambient Air Quality Standards for SO2 From 1971-2012
Final Rule/Decision Primary/ Secondary Indicator (1) Averaging Time Level (2) Form

1971

36 FR 8186
Apr 30, 1971

Primary

SO2

24-Hour

0.14 ppm

Not to be exceeded more than once per year

Annual

0.03 ppm

Annual arithmetic average

Secondary

3-Hour

0.5 ppm

Not to be exceeded more than once per year

Annual (3)

0.02 ppm

Annual arithmetic average

1973

38 FR 25678
Sept 14, 1973

Secondary

Secondary 3-hour SO2 standard retained, without revision; secondary annual SO2 standard revoked.

1996

61 FR 25566
May 22, 1996

Primary

Existing primary SO2 standards retained, without revision.

2010

75 FR 35520
Jun 22, 2010 (4)

Primary

SO2

1-hour

75 ppb

99th percentile, averaged over 3 years (5)

Primary annual and 24-hour SO2 standards revoked.

2012

77 FR 20218
April 3, 2012

Secondary

Existing secondary SO2 standard (3-hour average) retained, without revision.

(1)SO2 = sulfur dioxide

(2) Units of measure are in parts per million (ppm) and parts per billion (ppb).

(3)The 1971 final rule also included a secondary 24-hour SO2 standard of 0.1 ppm, maximum 24-hour concentration not to be exceeded more than once per year, as a guide to be used in assessing implementation plans to achieve the annual standard.

(4)The 1-hour SO2 standard added in 2010 is a primary standard. 

(5)The form of the 1-hour standard is the 3-year average of the 99th percentile of the yearly distribution of 1-hour daily maximum SO2 concentrations.

Learn more about setting and reviewing standards to control SO2 pollution.
item.dc:creator: smays

item.title: SO2 Data Requirements Rule Source List
item.description:
Related Information

  • SO2 Data Requirements Rule
  • SO2 Data Requirements Rule Source List
  • SO2 Data Requirements Rule State Pathway Notifications

The SO2 Data Requirements Rule (DRR) states that air agencies must, at a minimum, identify and characterize air quality around SO2 sources that emit 2,000 tons per year (tpy) or more of SO2 and submit a list of sources to EPA by January 15, 2016 based on the most recently available annual emissions data.  

To help identify maximum 1-hour SO2 concentrations in ambient air, the SO2 (sulfur dioxide) the DRR provides air agencies the option to:

1) to provide data to characterize current ambient SO2 air quality through modeling or monitoring in areas with large sources of SO2; or

2) to establish federally enforceable emission limits for a source that ensures that the source will emit less than 2,000 tpy of SO2.

State List Submittals and EPA Responses (January 15, 2016):

  • Region 1 (Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Vermont)
  • Region 2 (New Jersey, New York, Puerto Rico)
  • Region 3 (Delaware, District of Columbia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, West Virginia)
  • Region 4 (Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee)
  • Region 5 (Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio, Wisconsin)
  • Region 6 (Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas)
  • Region 7 (Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska)
  • Region 8 (Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakaota, Utah, Wyoming)
  • Region 9 (Arizona, California, Hawaii, Nevada, Pacific Islands)
  • Region 10 (Alaska, Idaho, Oregon, Washington)

* List of sources to be addressed under the Data Requirements Rule. Includes both sources listed by the state or tribe and sources listed by EPA. This list was posted on April 13, 2016, and was amended on May 24, 2016, to remove a source in the state of Texas, and was amended on June 28, 2016, to remove two sources in the state of Minnesota. The letters from Texas and from Minnesota to EPA requesting removal of these sources, and EPA’s responses, are posted in the Data Requirements Rule (DRR) Source List PDF below. 

  • Data Requirements Rule (DRR) Source List (PDF)(12 pp, 347 K, 06/23/2016)
item.dc:creator: rcopland

item.title: Technical Assistance Documents for Implementing the 2010 Sulfur Dioxide Standard
item.description:
EPA is making available two updated draft documents that provide technical assistance for states implementing the 2010 health-based, sulfur dioxide (SO2) standard.  These documents provide technical advice on the use of modeling and monitoring to determine if an area meets the 2010 SO2 air quality standard.

For more information see Sulfur Dioxide State Implementation Plan (SIP) Checklist Guide.

  • Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) National Ambient Air Quality Standards Designations Modeling Technical Assistance Document (August 2016 DRAFT) (PDF)(72 pp, 1 MB)
  • Source-Oriented Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) Monitoring Technical Assistance Document (February 2016 Draft) (PDF)(30 pp, 3 MB)
item.dc:creator: rcopland
